Authors: Takamichi Orihara, Muneyuki Ohmae, Kohei Yamamoto
Title:
First report of Chamonixia caespitosa (Boletaceae, Boletales)
from Japan and its phylogeographic significance
Keywords:
Conservation, Relict species, Sequestrate fungi,
Systematics
Abstract:
The rare sequestrate fungus, Chamonixia caespitosa, is
known to occur in Europe and North America. The species has also been
reported once from China, but the precise information on its occurrence
in Asia is unknown. We collected fruiting bodies of C. caespitosa in a
subalpine coniferous forest in central Japan. The ITS phylogeny shows
that the Japanese collections are more closely related to one of the
North American infraspecific lineages than to the European lineage.
Thus, these Japanese collections could be a missing link in the
phylogeography of the genus Chamonixia.
